messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Shin-Gunto Opinions
messages.msgSnippet: Kieth, Yeah, well, I was wrong on the 1935 date. This sword is dated 1940 - just like it should be. Sorry about that. As an archeologist I am interested the
messages.messageBody:
Kieth,
Yeah, well, I was wrong on the 1935 date. This sword is dated 1940 - just
like it should be. Sorry about that. As an archeologist I am interested the
2600 dates. At least some archeologists got in trouble for questioning the
mythical creation story, so the idea that somebody was beating that drum in
1935 caught my eye. Unfortunately, the actual number - Showa 15 - did NOT
equally catch my eye.
1940 not 1935!
Peter


Peter Bleed
Professor of Anthropology
810 Oldfather Hall
University of Nebraska
Lincoln, NE 68588-0368
(402) 472-2439

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: Shin-Gunto Opinions

messages.messageBody:
Thanks Peter,

No wonder there's so much text!
Would certainly appreciate the full translation if I can get this sword.
By the way, what's the Token list?

All the best,

Keith

----- Original Message -----
From: Peter A Bleed
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, August 03, 2007 2:04 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Shin-Gunto Opinions



Keith,
Interesting sword! I am not with my library at the moment, but this
certainly should meet anybody's definition of shin-gunto suitable for a
WWII display. Smith was a person named Katsumura Masakatsu. He appears to
have had/claimed a traditional title (hitatchi no suke??)and an honorary
affiliation (minamoto). The nengo is way cool. Looks like he made it in
1935 to commemorate the 2600 anniversary of the founding of the imperial
line - which did not occur until 1940. VERY patriotic. Way cool.
This sword might get more traction on the Token list.
Thanks for the posting. This looks like a very nice sword.
Peter

Peter Bleed
Professor of Anthropology
810 Oldfather Hall
University of Nebraska
Lincoln, NE 68588-0368
(402) 472-2439

----- Original Message -----
From: akeithsimmons
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, August 03, 2007 1:30 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Shin-Gunto Opinions


Hi group,

I will leave it to the moderator to decide if this message is
appropriate for the group, as it's more of a militaria than art sword
question.
Anyway, I need the groups help on a shin-gunto sword that is needed
for a WWII display and I thought you would certainly be well
qualified.
I've enclosed links to some pics which will help.
My studies of this type sword are limited, but this example seems to
match up well as authentic. However, with all of the repros being
produced I want to be as sure as I can before any purchase.
My concern with this particular sword is the excessive amount of text
seen on the nakago. I have never seen a published example with so much
writing. It almost appears overdone on purpose so as to make the
piece look authentic.
Would appreciate the group's opinion on this and any other aspects of
the sword that may look suspicious to you.
http://tinyurl.com/yok5wk
http://tinyurl.com/22ek8o
http://tinyurl.com/29vkog
http://tinyurl.com/2bx95b
http://tinyurl.com/26qmfv

These should post as clickable links, but if not I'll be glad to
upload them to the photo section.

Thanks,

Keith Simmons





[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
